reviewTitle: Great Price, Great Quality, Little Drawback
reviewDescription: I record a lot of voice over work for various projects, and I needed a mic that was able to adapt to any situation I had. With the four different settings and easy to alter gain, I found it simple to get high quality recordings with less setup and effort. Although this is a great mic, there are minor drawbacks to it here and there. I will try my best to cover everything informatively.Pros:+ USB Mic+ Gain Knob+ 1-to-1 audio feedback+ Works with common mic stands+ 4 different recording settings+ Heavy metal mount included+ Great Customer SupportCons:+ Mic is a bit heavy+ USB 2.0+ Slightly Awkward lengthFor the most part, theworks like a champ. Able to record quality audio under a multitude of situations. There are a lot of little touches that make it worth the extra bit you pay compared to the. The quality far outweighs the price you pay, especially for a USB mic. I have primarily stuck to using twofor the past few years and upon getting the Yeti have only run into a few specific moments where using the MXL's is a better choice.One of the noticeable parts of this mic is how reliable it looks. The metal cover, the well painted black coat and the firm weight. It is worth mentioning that the mic itself does weigh a little bit heavier than normal mics, though if you have a decent mic stand (or use the one it comes with) you shouldn't have any issues. In terms of audio quality, it is fairly high for the price you pay. I've had my experience with bad USB mics before, but the Yeti is solid. It doesn't pickup any noise from the USB, it is great at picking up high or low voices as well. It will take some trial and error, but once you get the correct gain level set you will find yourself enamored with how well you sound.I purchased aand I highly recommend doing so if you plan to do solo recordings. The yeti is very sensitive and can easily pick up background noises if your gain is too high, but it can also pick up blowing into the mic even better (a problem for those of us who have a lisp). It's not much of a complaint, as almost any mic responds the same in the given situation, just a pro tip.I found that the knobs are really durable and smooth to move. My only complaint is that the knobs on the back for the gain and the input setting are the same type, so I often have to take a second to make sure I am not changing the wrong one. Minute complaint, but wish the mic input knob was the same type as the headphone volume knob. The mute button feels a bit flimsy, but with how rarely you'll likely push it, I doubt it will start falling off anytime soon (unless you brute mash it every time).I included the picture of the box in the review, which outlines the different settings the mic has, but let me explain them a bit more:- Cardioid: Perfect for doing solo recordings, it comes in crisp and clear, with almost little gain necessary.- Bidirectional: Perfect for duo recordings. One person sits on either side of the mic and basically talks face to face.- Omnidirectional: Perfect for conference recordings. It records in every direction, but the quality of the audio is lower significantly to focus on picking up any and every noise possible within a given radius.- Stereo: Perfect for Group Calls. It records in front, left, and right of the mic. It is great when recording multiple people in a skype call as the audio coming from behind the mic isn't getting picked up.When I first got the mic I realized that the majority of my computers have USB 3.0 slots on them, so heading over to their website, I checked to see if the mic would perform well on usb 3.0. At the moment there are instances where the mic will not work properly over USB 3.0, but it is a hit or miss situation. It is a shame that the mic doesn't 100% support USB 3.0, but this problem can usually be rectified with a powered USB 2.0 hub. The website itself also has a great amount of support documents for those with questions regarding the device. Highly recommended for first time microphone users.overall, if you are in the market for a new microphone, I highly recommend checking out the Blue Yeti. It has great quality, for a great price with little drawback.** I also use this Microphone with my PS4 and my Elgato, and it works perfectly fine. I haven't run into any issues with either so far. Again it takes a bit of time to setup the gain properly, but once it is set, you sound better than everyone else! **

reviewTitle: Excelente micrófono de entrada, para streaming, gaming o podcasting
reviewDescription: Debido a las nuevas tendencias en redes sociales y a la constante demanda de contenido de buena calidad audiovisual, en algún punto como productor audiovisual sabes que tienes que subir al siguiente nivel de calidad en tu contenido, empezando por el auditivo, de ahí que busques los micrófonos que están siendo tendencia actualmente. Sin embargo, la gran mayoría nos hemos llevado la impactante noticia de que no basta con pagar lo que cuesta un Shure SM7b o un Rode para llegar a sonar como los mejores streamers o podcasters del momento, porque a pesar de no ser un desembolso de dinero considerable su compra (entre 300 y 500 USD), el solo microfono no basta, debes sumar lo que cuesta una buena interfaz de audio (100 -250 USD) y un preamplificador como los de Dynimate o Cloudlifter que también rondan unos 150 USD; en el mejor de los casos sería una inversión de 600 USD como mínimo.Y aunque es cierto que con buen conocimiento y buen manejo de postproducción, el nivel del contenido será magnifico ¿realmente es necesario gastar entre 600 - 900 USD de entrada, cuando aún no dominas programas como Ableton o logic Pro y lo unico que nesecitas es uun amplificador vocal, un buen compresor y ecualizador? Pues aquí es donde Logitech y su solución, el Blue Yeti y el Yeti nano (porque ahora Blue es de Logitech y por esa misma razón ellos te brindarán soporte técnico y te garantizan una adecuada integración con los demás perifericos en su interface GHub). Todos esos componentes mencionados anteriormente, vienen integrados en el Blue Yeti, por al rededor de 100 USD (cabe resaltar que hay sus diferencias en calidad entre un sistema con todo integrado y comprar cada componente por aparte), pero si lo que quieres es subir al siguiente escalón en calidad de audio, sin tener que gastar más de 500 USD en múltiples componentes que tendrás que aprender a controlar y ver cuál es la mejor configuración para que trabajen en su mejor nivel, y solo quieres conectar tu microfono a la PC y usarlo inmediatamente, con la confianza de que una marca de renombre te dará respaldo sobre su funcionamiento, este Logitech Yeti es para ti.

reviewDescription: So, I got my hands on the Blue Yeti Mic a while ago, it's been great for my recording and streaming setup. The audio quality is mostly fantastic (has some slight feedback issues.) It's a simple plug-and-play setup, so I didn't have to mess around with any complicated installations or extra equipment. Just plug it into my computer, and I'm good to go. Plus, the sleek and stylish blackout design adds to my setup.The Blue Yeti offers four different pickup patterns, which is a big plus. It's versatile enough to handle any situation. Whether I want to focus on my own voice, capture the whole room, conduct interviews, or even record in stereo, this microphone has got me covered.Now, there is one small thing worth mentioning. I did experience a bit of a feedback issue when using the microphone at higher volume levels. It's not a deal-breaker for me, but it would have been nice if the microphone handled those levels a bit better. It's something to keep in mind if you tend to crank up the volume.The microphone is a solid choice for anyone looking to up their recording or streaming game. The sound quality is great, and the flexibility of the pickup patterns is a huge plus. Just be mindful of the feedback at higher volume levels. That being said, I highly recommend giving this microphone a try!

Hi!I rarely do reviews on Amazon, but I felt this product needed one as after only a year (maybe a little less all-in-all), the mic stopped working. And customer service has not followed through with the replacement they promised.When it still worked, I used my mic for business - Skype calls, Webinars, and gaming. Then one day it just stopped working. There was no red light (below mute) and my computer did not even recognize that the Yeti was plugged in. So, I did some research and here is what I was able to confirm about the mic:- The port is not the issue: I tried several other USB ports on my computer (both in the front and back), all of which worked with other devices, but not the Yeti (I also tried plugging it in to our other two computers, but no success);- The cord is not the issue: I tried four back-ups that I had for other devices, all of which worked with other devices, but not the Yeti; and- There are no external defects with the mic that I can see (it's still as beautiful as the first day I got it!).So, what that leaves is an internal issue with the mic, which is why I touched base with Blue about it, because I like Blue, and had heard their customer service was good. And at first, they were good - they asked for various confirmations that I owned the mic, which of course I gave them. Then I didn't hear back. Hmm, I thought, that's weird.So I forwarded their former email asking for my confirmations, and suddenly they responded, telling me it was covered by warranty and that a replacement would be sent. However, they noted, there was an inventory count and transaction freeze, so they would be unable to ship orders for 3-5 weeks. I said no problem, because like I said, I like Blue. I bet you can guess what happened next.A confirmation email never came (they said one would, but it didn't), so I went ahead and contacted them after allowing an extra couple of weeks because hey, they said there was an inventory count and transaction freeze, and maybe it was taking longer than they anticipated. I am not in manufacturing, so what do I know?They have not returned that contact, which I would like to point out, was very respectful and understanding, as I have been all along, and as I will continue doing, because I have worked in customer service before and I know how difficult it can be. But as I said when I started writing this review - this mic is for business - and I have lost time and revenue because I have had to use a back-up that presented its own host of problems.So, TL;DR - if you want a mic that is great, but may only last for a year or less, then this is the perfect mic for you! If - for a price > $100 - you want a mic that lasts longer than a year, go elsewhere. There are many mics in this price range that are great for business and gaming that I would have rather had (and may be forced to buy soon) if I had known my Yeti would only last a year or less.Hope this helps!

reviewTitle: Defective product - no responses or help from Blue
reviewDescription: I purchased the Blue Yeti a few months ago, and it has been a headache the entire time I have owned it. Now, let me preface this with the fact that I suspect I received a defective product. There are a couple issues with this however:1) I have troubleshooted the product extensively, and the sheer number of issues that people have had with this product in trying to produce decent quality sound make it difficult to determine if my product is faulty or if I am just experiencing one of the myriad problems it has.2) I have been waiting about 2 weeks for any kind of response on the official Blue website for any kind of help troubleshooting my Yeti. I'm not sure what kind of customer service staff they have available, or how behind they are on requests. At this point though, I am unsure how long of a wait I should expect as there has been zero feedback.Pros:- This is a heavy mic, it really feels like you're pulling a professional recording device.- Comes with a very sturdy desk stand (although it's recommended to mount on an arm or boom stand which is separate).- Seems to have great audio when I've listened to folks recording YouTube videos.- Has an easy to use knob on the back of the mic to adjust the recording angle of the mic.- Another knob on the back to adjust gain on the fly.- Easy to access mute switch on the front of the mic to mute in a flash.Cons:- Not a device you just plug and play (unless you really luck out). There are a lot of tweaks that need to be made to avoid feedback and make sure your sound is crystal clear.- I didn't experience issues with this, but people report often that this picks up excessive sound from their recording space (expected, it's a powerful mic).- Customer service for this product seems non-existent.I hope to eventually replace this device with another Yeti that works so I can write a proper review. Until I hear back from Blue though, I absolutely cannot recommend this product. A little research on audio forums will yield a lot of great suggestions for alternatives that have way fewer issues.

reviewTitle: Experienced engineer - Found this mic to be middling, literally and figuratively.
reviewDescription: I've been doing semi-pro audio recording and building and using mic chains since the early 90s, used a lot of mics--AT, Neumann, etc. My ATR2100 USB I use for Zoom developed a dumb short (design fault probably) pretty early on so I decided to give this mic a shot because it was popular.This mic lacks bass and presence, in comparison. It distorts easier on transients and plosives than the ATR. I am not expecting perfection out of either since USB is probably not an optimal input connection and more importantly because these mics are not connected to dedicated preamps or compressors, but the Yeti sounds about as good as a Shure SM57, probably a little worse.It's not a terrible mic but I did shootouts with both the ATR as well as the Realtek onboard mic on my wife's Razer laptop, and she passed on this mic because it required proximity (due to cardioid pattern) just to even sound as good as the onboard sound on the razer.It's a little "hotter" than onboard sound so if you want the ability to be louder by moving closer or messing with the mic pattern, this can help--but the gain volume is not especially good sounding and it distorts on peaks more easily than onboard sound and the ATR.Testing this mic convinced me to stick with Audio Technica for USB mics. It's cool that it has a little monster mascot and what not but IMO it seems like a lot of people are getting caught up in branding instead of talking to audio engineers, or else Amazon still has an astroturfing problem. If Neumann made a USB mic I'd have that because I am a Neumann devotee, but they do not and I am too lazy to figure out a way to adapt my AD converter to USB, just for dayjob audio.I will keep it as a backup since I hate dealing with returns, but I am not super impressed with it and I wish I would have spent the money on the ATR2500 instead. So this review is my pound of flesh for the wasted cash.If you don't believe me, take a look at the response pattern overlay I attached. Having a relatively flat mic response is good for situations where you are expecting to add sheen and bass (essentially loudness) via compression and EQ, but this is a USB mic, not a studio mic, and there is no mic chain phase, so I don't know why a flat mic that sounds like an instrument mic would be a good thing for this application.

For gaming it's totally fine, but if you're producing podcasts or video, this is going to cause you serious headaches in editing. I expected better out of Blue given how amazing the Snowball was for me for so many years.

reviewTitle: Gorgeous mic with terrible drivers but decent recording capabilities?
reviewDescription: Now before I get into details, I want to point out that I've owned this mic twice. Once in 2010, when I was still relatively ignorant in the ways of recording, and now in 2015. I'm able to notice things now that I wasn't able to notice then, and the biggest thing I'd like to point out is that this not the best mic for creating quality music. Sure, it sounds decent, but you shouldn't record music at 16-bit quality (the quality this mic outputs) unless it's live, a demo, or some other semi-professional application. IF you're looking for a place to start however, the Blue Yeti is great.I purchased the mic with basic demo recording and mix practicing in mind. I plan to get a better condensor (probably another Blue) over time.Build quality: It's a solid build, featuring one of the finest designs I've ever seen. It's bulk basically prohibits you from using it in a mobile setup, but it is right at home on a desk workstation or living room table. My only nag is that it doesn't come with a pop filter (easily obtained and cheap) or a shockmount. There are alternative shockmounts out there, with the best one that will fit a Yeti being above 50$. The size makes it hard to find a suitable mount, but there are alternatives to decouple your mic otherwise (possibly with foam?). The Blackout edition is gorgeous, matches my studio setup nicely. 4/5 STARSInstallation/Drivers: USB Mics are trouble, no matter what you get. But this is among the worst software troubles I have ever seen. I like to record and mix all at once, but it seems that to get the Yeti to cooperate with ASIO drivers, you're going to be jumping through many hoops. I use Studio One Artist as my main Recording DAW, and I have yet to find a way to properly listen to my recordings through my speakers with no troubles. The woes of a USB mic, I suppose. Don't expect too much from this mic in the way of ease. 2/5 STARSSound quality: 16 bit quality recording. Great for podcasting, videos, etc. NOT recommended for professional audio recording by any stretch. If you're looking for a good audio recording setup, buy an Audio Interface and Mic separate. For 130$ you cannot beat this as a complete solution, but even a SM58+Scarlett setup is recommended over this (for double the price of course). BUT to reiterate, this makes a great mic for simple podcasts and what not. 4/5 STARSOverall: I love to look at it, hate to install it, like to record with it. It's not the best mic, nor would you spend 130$ looking for the best mic. But for what it is, you can't beat it. Again, NOT recommended for professional audio recording.

It picks up so much background noise so much that you actually have to configure it to ensure it doesnt.I have my gain slider at 9'0 clock the 4 options for the mic is the bean looking one, and then I had to go into windows, edit sound settings and turn the volume of the mix to 65, disable audio enhancements, switch the quality to highest, and then put the mic through VoiceMeeter Potato with the Denoiser MAXED with the gate at 4.5.It is an understatement when I say it will pick up anything and everything in the background regardless of what it is. Still a good sounding mic though.3/5 since I had to actually configure it to be usable and pleasant to others who hear me over the internet.

reviewTitle: Hyper Sensitive Mic Makes It Unusable
reviewDescription: I have been using the Blue Yeti for over a year. I first purchased it for work because I needed something that wasn't a headset so it would appear more professional while presenting to customers remotely. After purchasing and setting up the mic I quickly realized that this mic was crazy sensitive even using all the tricks like turning the gain all the way down and changing the audio direction. If you have your kid on the other side of your mansion and they are playing with toys... this might pick it up. All joking aside though, it is too sensitive to be of practical use to a normal person. I have gone out and dropped several hundred dollars on "extras" such as covers, adjustable table arms, software to try and control the keyboard noises coming through and it still just captures everything. If you want the other person to hear everything that is going on around you to include scratching, moving your chair, typing, clicking on your mouse, sometimes their own voice because this will detect the noise from you headphones, or even breathing if you don't have the proper external extensions then this is the mic for you. For everybody else, I would recommend another microphone.

I thought this mic would be an upgrade for my home office, but it’s so frustrating. The mic loses connectivity constantly. Only way to fix it is to disconnect and connect the usb again. I bought it on Black Friday because I thought it’s a good deal, but I should have done more research about the mic. You can find so many articles and videos about the issues I have with it. reviewTitle: I contacted Blue Yeti and Hazel was really nice and was willing to have me come by to ...
reviewDescription: Don't buy this if you are going to use it soon for something important unless you have time to tinker with it.  I tried three different operating systems and none of them detect the microphone.  I went to the store to buy two different mini usb cables, even a gold plated one and still no computer detects the microphone.  I contacted blue yeti and they suggested to buy a new cable which I did and they suggested really basic troubleshooting steps and still nothing.  I contacted Blue Yeti and Hazel was really nice and was willing to have me come by to get the microphone replaced early tomorrow morning.  However the interview I had purchased it for is tomorrow at 9AM so that is really not an option even if they do open at 8AM I would be stuck in traffic on the way back to my office.  I am really disappointed in such a product being that it has good reviews.  I was shocked to hear that putting pressure on the USB part of the microphone was an actual troubleshooting option.  I would not want to break the microphone because then it would be physical damage and then I would be without warranty.  DONT BUY IF YOU NEED IT TO WORK RIGHT AWAY, unless you have time to fiddle with it.

reviewTitle: So I recently bought this mic after a few days ...
reviewDescription: So I recently bought this mic after a few days of research and debating either the blue yeti or the seiren x. The mic came in on time and it was brand new, was very worried at first because of other reviews stating people were getting chip paint or used ones. They do work very well in windows 10 and they pick up just about everything. I had to turn the gain all the way down to limit the background noise as I do have children. After 1 night had to opt into buying a boom arm because even with a water cooled system that you can not hear with the human ear, the mic was picking up the vibrations on the desk from the water pump. This was taken care of by the boom arm.

So far, the mic is on point. It doesn't sound muffled or anything like that. The thing that I noticed is, the volume knob is grindy. I can turn it about half way, with no resistance, but the other half starts grinding. It's not an audible grinding sound, at least to the human ear. It kind of feels like a mouse wheel, but inconsistent. I'm not sure what's going on? I don't use the volume knob, so that's the good thing.The quality of the package is amazing. *Thumbs up* Unfortunately, I have to rate the Blue Yeti mic to 4 stars, due to the grinding knob.Amazon, the review asks me to rate the camera quality? *Confused face* This isn't a camera…

I know they sell a blue yeti with xlr but it doesn't seem like it should cost twice as much to get one other connection option.It does sound good and I am overall pretty happy with it, maybe I just need to do a bit more research to figure out the best ways to use it.

reviewTitle: The mini USB cable is trash, buy another one
reviewDescription: UPDATE: 3.5 years into it, the sound stop working from the mic- tested on 3 computers. Out of warranty so it's now trash. Everyone says my voice is really good with this mic, might consider another but will look around.--This mic would get 5/5 from me for value, quality (physical, and sound), construction, etc. However, it loses  two stars for one simple reason: the mini-USB cable it comes with is absolute garbage. You get a company that makes an absolutely beautiful piece of art for a product, and throw in a trash USB cable that doesn't work. It barely works, has to be wiggled a lot while you keep your fingers crossed it stays in place, and then you have to pray it doesn't cut out in the middle of your recording. I almost returned the microphone because of that (in fact, it was obvious my microphone was opened carefully before me, and probably the person before me returned it). I researched what the issue was and many people online claimed the cable was trash, so I bought a new cable from Amazon (a simple Amazon Basics cable) and now the mic works perfectly without any loss in connection. I took 2 starts off because the cable literally killed the product for me, and I know I'm not the only one. Blue, if you guys wise up, throw in a better cable and your product might have more stellar ratings and less returns.

reviewTitle: Sounds great, but buggy when used with iMac
reviewDescription: The mic feels very well built, and the sound quality is excellent. (That said, it is VERY sensitive, so it does require careful positioning, gain tuning, and using with background noise suppression software to get the best out of it.)The biggest issues I have is its compatibility with iMac: the mic always stops working after iMac goes to sleep and wakes up. The USB device still shows in the OSX Sounds dialog correctly, but the audio level just won't move. The only way I found to resolve this is to unplug and plug the USB cable. Also, when used with Blue Sherpa app to control its gain and direct monitoring, the settings always get reset to default after the USB cable is unplugged. This means every time I wake up my iMac, I always need to unplug/plug the USB cable and reset the gain/direct monitoring to get the mic working properly. It's doable, but definitely an annoyance that can be avoided if Blue pays a bit more care into their OSX driver.

It sounds the same, if not worse because it is not right up next to my mouth like the headset was.Also, the mute button does not work every time you press it and that is kind of important to me because I use voice-activation on teamspeak so I have to use a hotkey to mute since the mute button has to be pressed 2-3 times for it to actually mute. Also the red light is always on and it blinks when you mute, would be better design to be off all the time and be solid red when muted like most other headsets do that I have had this way it is 100% clear when it is muted.Overall I am not impressed and I do not understand why people use this for streaming/podcast purposes when any headset mic has the same voice quality. reviewTitle: Great Product -- Fail on Customer Serivce and Quality Assurance
reviewDescription: The mic itself is great... the issue I have is the customer service and the quality assurance or lack there of.The mic has great lows, limits the breathiness of most mics that don't have the triple cage. However, the mic stand, which should have 3 pads on the bottom only had two. I figured this wouldn't be a big deal, so I contacted Blue and initially the customer service sounded promising. I needed the mic and couldn't go without it, so I requested that a new pad be sent. I sent them photos that it was missing a pad and had zero adhesive residue meaning it was never on. The customer service person made it sound like they could send one out. Then I received an email a couple days later stating I had to send the whole thing back. I responded to that email of asking why and I haven't heard anything back from them for the past 3 weeks.*Pic* Gotta love the missing pad on the bottom of the stand right next to the sticker "QC Passed"... says something doesn't it.The mic itself is 5 star for price and use, but minus one star for the lack of Quality assurance/quality control on the stand and minus another star for customer service not being able to simply send one adhesive pad to fix their mistake and not responding to emails for weeks on end.

reviewDescription: I've had nothing but issues with this product. The cable needs to be replaced every 3 or so months. reviewTitle: Microphone USB port stopped working within a year.
reviewDescription: TL;DR Within a year my microphone's USB port stopped working, after troubleshooting no solution could be found I was then sent a replacement with abnormally bad / fuzzy sound quality. Eventually I was sent a functioning mic. Your experience with the product and Blue's CS may vary.I bought the Blue Yeti Microphone as a step up from my headphones. Within the year I encountered an issue, when I attempted to plug the included USB cable into the microphone I heard four static pops in my headphones after which the microphone became completely inoperable. Despite my experimentation with other USB cables and long hours spent pouring over forums and YouTube tutorials I was unable to find a solution to the problem. I contacted support and sent in my microphone for testing and received a seemingly brand-new replacement within a week. When using this new microphone the audio quality was abnormally bad when compared to the original microphone, delivering an intense, fuzzy sound quality. After sending in the replacement I was eventually sent a new and functioning product.Blue's Yeti Mic is a good value and that value sometimes comes at a price. The product has its flaws but Blue's CS tried to make up for them and that's better than nothing.

The package was in perfect condition, the box was in perfect condition, the product was far from. It was scratched and beat up, and even after hours of trying to make it work, it wouldn't. The port the cable goes into was so loose the cable wouldn't stay in. So the microphone wouldn't turn on, couldn't be set up, etc. For a product that's supposed to be "invaluable" and an "investment" it sure arrived in the poorest condition of anything I've ordered online, in a long time.

I've been an AV professional for decades.  Bought this for improved audio on Zoom calls.  The Mute button is an all important feature. But Blue decided to use a non-standard mute button indication.  The industry standard is - red light on - mic is muted.  Light off - or green - mic is unmuted. This is the way all PTT mics work.  Many of them offer options to change these settings.  Blue chose to "blink" the light when muted - which NO ONE does - and to have it solid red when it's on. REALLY?? Who designs this stuff!  That would trip me up on every Zoom call.  And there is no software option to change it. Back in the box it goes.  GHEEZ!!!

The internal DAC malfunctioned on mine, now not only does it only record only on the right channel and have a static noise, but the usb port has difficulty maintaining a connection.This wouldn't be so big of a deal if it weren't for how lightly I've used this thing, it's mostly been in storage and handled gently when in use.Not only that, but good luck getting Blue Microphones to service it, it took them over two weeks to respond to my issue and they just asked for a proof of warranty despite me saying I most likely didn't have one and that I'd like to pay for a repair.The only reason I gave this two stars instead of one, is because for the very few recordings I DID get to do, it had a great quality sound for the price.Bottom line: Either get a long warranty or don't get a USB microphone, get a regular one and an external dac. There's too much that can mess up with a USB mic. I'm probably going to go Audio Technica next.

It is a good solid microphone - and for reference, I've been using pro broadcast quality equipment in my work since the 1970's.  However the way the Yeti USB cable connects at the bottom of the microphone is badly designed in a way that leaves it prone to getting broken.  The microphone stand has a swivel to adjust for various angles that is very solidly built but if the microphone swings in the wrong direction it will hit (and can break) the connector.  This has to do with the swivel screws and the stand design.  This design flaw made my Yeti unusable after one wrong turn.  I am enough impressed with the mic over all to buy a 2nd, replacement one.  But I'm NOT happy that I had to.  Be ware.  Be careful that the swivel screws are tightened.  If they are loose or the mic is turned the wrong direction it can irreparably break the connector.

This microphone does not have very clear sound. It is muffled (even without any cover) and I spent hours trying to get the settings right and was not successful. I could never get the sound to go above -30 on audacity. Even tapping the microphone did not spike any higher.I ended up purchasing a different brand of microphone. It was easier to install (plug and play) and the sound quality was immediately clear. Tapping on this new mic produced spikes on the meter.I don't suggest the Yeti mic if you are looking for high quality voice recordings.

I recently purchased this mic. I'm returning it after 24 hours. Sound quality is fine. The biggest disappointment of this product is that the various "directional" mic patterns are almost entirely uselss. I was hoping to have a dedicated mic with desktop speaker setup. Unfortunately regardless of positioning or directional mic setting, this picks up everything!Definitely a fine product if you are purely recording or using headphones, but if there are background noises you are worried about picking up, this mic is going to pick them up. The directional settings will not help.

Not once, not twice, but three times did the exact same thing happen to me. The port of the Mic itself becomes damaged with time, no matter what you do with the cable angle. The first time it happened i figured "must be my fault i shouldn't have had the cable at a hard angle and so tight" so I gave the cable slack and let it have ample wiggle room to move so it wouldn't tug at the new mic's port. Same thing happened within a week. The third Mic from blue yeti had issues out of the box, static and crackling coming over so other people thought i sounded like pop rocks. I don't know why this happens and I thought Blue was better than this so I'm very disappointed. Hopefully they can fix these issues.

I purchased this microphone from here in December of 2017. It came nicely packaged, and not damaged. The setup was easy, and it sounded pretty good minus picking up a lot of background noise (its a condenser). I had used it for a little more than a year, when it suddenly started to transmit a high pitched frequency. I could no longer use it while recording gameplay, or while talking to others. I tried isolating the wire away from other ones, I bought and tried using a usb hub, etc., but I couldn't get the noise to go away. So I gave up on it, and put the mic away, where its been sitting since.Bottom line is, it was a good mic while it lasted. I just wish it lasted longer.

The problem I am experiencing is the USB Ports I plug into. The USB port on my laptop is USB 3.1. I dont know anything about computers but after hours of research this YETI MIC has a USB 2.0. They are not compatible and the device will not work and cause a driver error. I have tried multiple solutions and unfortunate have to wait a month for my new PC to arrive before I can stream with a MIC. I am very worried that my NEW PC will have NEW USB PORTS 3.0 or 3.1 causing the same issue.. This is so frustrating I am thinking I will return the mic simply because USB 2.0 and 3.0 don' allow the mic to work properly.

I purchased this microphone with the intention of possibly opening a channel for a game I play online.The original setup was pretty easy but there is a learning curve involved to get real familiar with the proper settings and when to use them. I have owned this microphone for 5 months now and about a week ago it just quit working. I went through the recommended troubleshooting and even replaced the usb cord thinking it may have developed a short. It still does not function. My Operating system (Ubuntu Gnome) will no longer recognize the device. I filled out the support request form online at bluemic.com and received a reply back telling me it may be up to 5 days before someone contacts me because they are busier than normal (why is it that every time I call for support, regardless of the company, they are always busier than normal?).

reviewTitle: Avoid this microphone despite the positive reviews
reviewDescription: The USB connector on this microphone is not up to standard, and it will fail eventually. That's the main reason to avoid the Blue Yeti. The included USB cable started disconnecting after a few months and by the time I had been using it for a year, the microphone disconnected from the computer constantly. I changed out the cables and that worked for a while, but the connection started dropping again. Bottom line, and I'm not the only person who is complaining, the USB connection isn't solid.Additionally, the Blue Yeti is huge. When I ended up replacing it with an Audio Technica 2020 I realized just how oversized and cumbersome the Blue Yeti had been. Sound quality was fine while it worked, but for as much money as I paid, I wanted more than a year of functionality.

reviewTitle: NICE PRODUCT but didn't last as others
reviewDescription: We bought this microphone, no one use it except for one adult, we didn't move it is in one place. The cord is not working,it is not conecting anymore, I have been looking on how to get help, but you can't get anyone and Amazon just send you to pages and pages of information. We look on line and a lot of people has the same problem, but they bought it at a store so it was easy to get help

No matter how I've messed with my settings, I get insane background noise. If I turn my gain down on the mic, PC or wherever else I can then the mic sounds like I'm a mile from it even though it is sitting right next to me. For people to hear me speak clearly they hear end up hearing mouse click and keyboard stroke. Very disappointed!
Was sent a prior open box, it was retaped to hold the box together.
Dirty old mic.  returned

reviewTitle: Doesn't work with Windows 10! NO software drivers!
reviewDescription: Bought this about 5 months ago for my 13 year old son on his PC, which used windows 8 at the time and since then we have upgraded to windows 10. Stupid thing doesn't even show up as a device in the device manager. I double-checked this by plugging it into my computer (less than 1-year old HP 700-330qe with intel Core i7 chip and 12 GB RAM) and got a little window that popped up saying something to the effect of "unrecognized USB device". Didn't show up in my device manager either. Got on the company's website and there is no driver software for this mic at all, nothing. A $5 USB thumb drive I plug into my computer for the first time gets a download of software. So now we have a $107 door stop. Thanks Blue for the terrible customer support. You could have at least kissed me first!

What the hell..... It works fine when the Windows can detect it. So far I have had two times when windows cannot detect it. None of the solutions online help and Blue's website doesn't offer help. Most tell you to uninstall and reinstall the driver in device manager, but the doesn't work if the device doesn't even show up there!!!!! Extremely frustrating. Why have a nice microphone if it can't even communicate with your computer properly.Update I found a video saying that the cable sucks. I replaced it and bingo it works. Still giving it a low rating for the nightmare I had to go through to make it work. If the update their product description warning ppl that the cable doesn't work and that should be the first place to troubleshoot then I will change my rating

reviewTitle: DO NOT buy Blue Yeti off of Amazon - B-stock garbage!
reviewDescription: I purchased the Blue Yeti from an authorized dealer and used it for about a year and totally loved it. For my second house I purchased another off of Amazon and from day 1 it was total junk. Hit or miss as to whether the audio would work. Imagine looking like a total buffoon in conference calls when your audio isn't working, or making a 10 minute screenshare video, only to discover that you didn't jiggle the USB connection enough to allow the audio to work properly and having to continuously redo your work. Horrible junk that has cost me time, money, and reputation incompetence among colleagues. Support is useless.

reviewTitle: Faulty connection -- continually coming unplugged from the computer
reviewDescription: I don't know if the one I received is defective, but this microphone absolutely will not work. The usb port on the mic itself is loose, and the cord continually falls out of it if the mic is bumped or even breathed on wrong. The sound quality is fine, but the physical item is simply faulty. Logitech has been completely unresponsive in my requests for support. Not recommended.
Mic is bad

reviewTitle: What is all the fuss about?
reviewDescription: I don't understand what all the fuss is about with this mic. I found the sound to be awful. As a singer I have a lot of experience with tons of different mics, bought this for my youtube channel, but I found the little $10 Lavalier mic I have created a much nicer sound. I wasn't paying attention and missed the return window on this mic and now I'm stuck with it. Annoying.

The quality on these is terrible. After three different ones, I won’t buy these anymore. First one had an extremely loud mute click that can be heard in your recording/calls. Turning the volume knob also created static. I ordered a second one with the yeti caster and I couldn’t even turn the volume knob, so I returned the whole kit (the boom is not very good either, very cheaply made). My original one broke a week ago (only four years old), so I ordered a new blackout one. The mute button is nicer, but the volume and gain knobs are terribly made and drag/scrape inside the housing when you try to turn them making them harder to turn and an awful noise. How did getting bought by Logitech make these things worse? Looks like I’ll be returning another one and buying something more expensive like a Rode or Shure, unfortunately. These just don’t cut it from a quality perspective. Additionally, the base is poorly designed and basically can’t be used if you’re using a mouse and keyboard, unless you turn the gain way up at which point a feather falling off a bird three miles away will be picked up because condenser mics pick up everything when the gain is high, but it won’t pick you up unless you crank it up and put it behind or beside your keyboard.

This product failed after a year in the middle of recording.  Since then, the support have confirmed receipt of my microphone, but weeks later have not given any update about it.  This is despite multiple emails, multiple ticket updates through their own site, multiple tickets submitted to their site, all resulting in complete radio silence from a company that now has essentially stolen my property.  No phone number is listed for any kind of support or customer contact, and the ones I've found for their physical offices go unanswered.  I've worked for many types and levels of support, and any time an email was not responded to in 1 hour was considered a failure.  This company took a WEEK to issue an automated/canned RMA email.  They confirmed receipt of my property once it was received, however no further update have been given in the weeks since.In short, they are incompetent thieves.  This is pathetic.  Avoid this company like the plague.

reviewTitle: nope for me, the mic biggest flaw is too big for me
reviewDescription: I'm sorry, I might be among the few that doesn't get along with it, after couple of moths of using it I just...can't use it, don't get me wrong, it record great sound, but it record everything it hears plus more sounds we can't even hear, and it ruins my recording every single time, to the point of today I've been recording a video in my living room, the refrigerator in the other side of the room is being herd like it's 1 meter away, at ever higher level than what I recorded in-front of the microphone, believe I tried playing with many option with the mic and software side, it just doesn't help, the gain you have on your mic, is just a volume level, the mic records will remain the same at all different level gains just in different level of volume, so if you want the outside noise to get out of your recording or something else, it is only software wise, and it's not suitable for me since it's reducing the audio quality, and I'm not into harsh audio editing each and every time I record something, it's a mic not for everyone, and it's not for me, I hate it because it doesn't did a single appropriate audio recording for me as I wanted it to, my suggestion, if you're in to silent recordings, don't get this mic be damn sure you live in the quietest place on earth, sorry its 1 star for me, now I need to sell it and find something else.If anyone has suggestions pls mail me at mikelt006@gmail.com I'll be happy to hear and explain forward if needed.

I don't understand why, after this amount of time, this does not install a Windows driver upon plugin. I could not get this to work on my system and there is NO information provided on how to obtain a driver. I did find some information on the WEB but there were many steps and procedures to TRY. I am very tech-savvy but was unwilling to TRY all the steps and various suggestions. A product like this should already be completely compatible with the operating system or at least provide you with the necessary steps to EASILY make it operational.

Won't even power on. I plugged it into 4 different computers to check if it was the usb port's issue and it never turned on. I'm guessing it came with a faulty power cable which should not happen when a $15 microphone can come in working condition and run with zero issues for over 3 years.

I bought this as a Christmas gift for my wife and she is just now setting up her podcast recording studio. We plugged the mic microphone to the phone and it doesn’t work. The box came with no instructions so there is no way to trouble shoot. Because we are setting  up her studio so long after Christmas the return window is closed. MAKE SURE TO CHECK IT WORKS AS SOON AS YOU BUY IT! I would love it if customer service would reach out to me.

reviewTitle: USB power port broken out of box
reviewDescription: The mic was working fine for like an hour and then randomly the port for the power became very loose and the cord was not fitting nor staying locked in the mic. There was no serious movement before this happend which means it was already very fragile and ready to unhook from the motherboard. Your practically playing heads or tails with this mic. Unfortunate

reviewTitle: Complete Trash since added to Logitech G-Hub
reviewDescription: This mic worked perfectly until stupid Logitech got involved and now my G-Hub software for my house screws my mic up every single time it updates.  It won't complete the update until I relaunch and for whatever the hell reason it has a voice overlay on until I go turn on and back off the overlay.  So stupid.  Like I mentioned, worked flawlessly when just using standard Windows drivers until more 'recently.'  I sure as hell will not buy again.Side note!  I used to be a huge logitech fan but their headphones and keyboards have gone to crap.  The last decent keyboard and headset they made were the original G15 and G35.  Those were built to last and lasted 10 years of gaming and working with them.  Not anymore.  You are lucky to get one year out of their headsets before wiring takes a dump.

reviewTitle: Logitech sent a USED microphone when purchased BRAND NEW
reviewDescription: I bought a BRAND NEW microphone and Logitech/Blue Yeti sent a used, opened box and product that had already been opened and had been used by someone previously. Second time around buying one of these mics after the first one died out after several years (purchased one way back before the Logitech acquisition), but this draws the line. You are seriously going to send me a USED product that looks REFURBISHED when I am paying full price for a NEW item. This one is going straight back and sticking with another brand as well as XLR. For anyone reading this to mimic the "amazing" sound quality that these microphones have just use an XLR microphone and route your audio into a DAW, apply some light EQ/Compression and vwalla, you will sound just like one of these mics.

Purchased for Zoom and Teams meetings for work.5-10 times a week a get a pop up that USB device is not recognized.  I plugged it into a USB hub, and had the issue.Also had the issue when plugging directly into my laptop.  I usually need  to restart my computer for it to show up again.IT goes out without notice, so when I am on calls, the audio defaults to the internal mic in my laptop without me knowing, resulting in poor call quality - or if I ntice it has me scrambling before meetings to restart my computer so my audio will work properly.I am not super tech savvy -- but i know how to plug in and set a USB device.  It should just work.  And I am fighting with it 5, 10+ times a week.

reviewTitle: Blue Yeti won't work anymore (Only two months of use)
reviewDescription: I would have given it a five star review for such amazing sound quality, but it's unfortunately no longer working after over two months of use.  I have tried everything to get it to work again...  Using a different USB cable, trying a different computer, trying different ports, resetting my input/laptop, etc...  I am unable to find the problem.  It hasn't fallen or been damaged as far as I am aware.  If anyone has had this problem and has fixed it, please let me know!  Otherwise, I loved it.

Purchased for a Christmas gift for my son, awesome mic but after only 3 months use the plug for the usb cord was loose and wouldn’t connect to the computer and we have yet to be able to find how to take it apart to tighten it.  Way to expensive to not last any longer than that

this is amazing if you are starting to stream or starting to get into pc gaming, however it costs a lot of money and I think you could get a better mic for 70$. but, but this is still a good mic if you are looking for a mic get a different one but if you already got this keep it.

reviewTitle: it works but its missing something
reviewDescription: well i orders this microphone and it works very well but when i opened the box for it welll. . . the peice to attach it to the boom arm was missing but other than that it works!

reviewTitle: Good sound, cheap mute button and gain/direction switch feel
reviewDescription: For the most part this is a good mic for the price but it's mute button is certainly very cheap feeling and inconsistent if you have to come off of mute quickly it will not always work. A bit of an irritation. Hopefully more updated version of the Yeti have fixed this issue.

reviewTitle: It's alright until it stops working
reviewDescription: I absolutely loved this microphone when I got it. It worked flawlessly for 2 months. And all of a sudden the mic just stopped working properly. It sounds super bass filled and I sound robotic, and have tried everything I can to fix it. I'm currently trying to get Blue Yeti's customer service to take my mic back so they can look at it but they kind of are giving me a hard time. I'm to the point where I'm just going to buy a new microphone from a different company. If customer services ends up taking my microphone back and fixes it, I'd give it 4 stars.

Good Mic .. but the mute button just stopped working all of a sudden .. when you hit the mute button and it's blinking, that means the mic is muted .. but mine which i barely used all of a sudden stopped muting on it's own. The light would be blinking and the sound still gets through. I have looked online and other people have had this same issue.  The sound quality on this mic is very good for the price overall.

I ordered one of these and loved it initially until I noticed it was picking up significantly louder on the left. I ordered a replacement and the replacement was worse.I loved everything else about it and would have been happy to keep it otherwise. If this isn't a big issue for you it would be a great, reasonably priced mic.
pretty good but finding the right settings to block out background noise etc is hard also just literally picks up everything  but maybe cause i just got a loud background

reviewTitle: Tolerance of threads for the thumbscrews too loose.
reviewDescription: This is my first microphone purchase. The holes for the thumbscrews were beyond tolerance, too loose.  The thumbscrews literally just pulled/fell out of the holes. I think the recording sound is fine, I do not have enough experience with microphones to say more than it meets my needs. I will buy another microphone and keep this one as a backup. I will figure out another stand for it.

Immediately after receiving the highly praised, I started to carefully unscrew the mount so that I can mount it to my boom arm.  That's when I realized some build quality issues (pictures included):- The area where the the mic connects with the stand shows paint chipping.- The pattern dial is not centered correctly within the hole/cutout.- The mute button has a very awkward click and feel.- Paint/coating shows tiny bubbles in some areas (see picture)Maybe this is only evident in the BLACKOUT EDITION and not the silver edition???.  Whatever the case may be, I am not happy with build quality of this USB microphone.  I have a great eye for detail and it sometimes is a double edged sword.  I want to like this but I can't get past these minor/major issues.  At this price point I would hope the build quality is top notch.  VERY DISAPPOINTED.

reviewTitle: Frankly, no better than my iPhone 11 mic.
reviewDescription: I was not impressed.  Compared it to my Logitech C615/1080P camera/mic and also my iPhone 11 mic.Was at best marginally better to my ears and one friend that I had listen to recordings I made with all 3.Bass was thin and mid-range "tinny" was our impression.However, I then purchased the Zoom H6 and totally impressed so far.  Actually sounds like me with dramatically greater utility!!  I purchased an Amazon "refurbished" unit that is in flawless condition - totally brand new appearance.  Well worth the extra cost for what my needs are (poetry reading for website with the added advantage of in the friend gathering of background sounds if needed.  Will also carry with me on trips for those impulsive "writing" moments.
After watching many YouTube videos and trying everything I could to get this product to work it didn’t. I then got a different microphone that worked just fine. Absolute garbage.

The first time I connected it, the microphone worked with no issues.  When I disconnected and reconnected it later on in the evening, the usb cable that came with the microphone would no longer stay tightly connected for some reason and would remain lose and the microphone was no longer detected by my computer.I also tried connecting the other end of the usb cable to different usb ports along with restarting my computer but the microphone was no longer being detected. I tried three other mini-usb cables to see if the issue was with the cable that came with the microphone.  Unfortunately, all of them had the same issue, pointing to the Microphone's USB port being the same issue.

reviewTitle: Came with broken pins and no one will answer how to get fixed under warranty
reviewDescription: Had problems with power from the beginning, but did not use since full time student with lots on my plate. Finally had someone look at it that showed me one of the pins that the power cord has to connect with is smashed, so either came that way or came with the pin out of alignment so that it mashed when I first yried to plug in. Now I can not find how to return this for repair under the warranty. Should have read all the reviews because the quality of the product and warranty support just isn't there.

1 star. The product itself is fantastic but be prepared for disappointment the moment something goes wrong with it. My Blue Yeti Blackout edition started adding static to everything. It took three weeks to get an RMA and after I sent it back I was told a replacement would be out 1-2 business days from arriving. Here we are 6 weeks later and no microphone, no response from Blue customer support, not update on my RMA, nothing. Avoid. We have to hold companies like this to higher standards. Just because you make a good and affordable product doesn't mean you can have customer service this bad and stay ahead.Buyer beware.

reviewTitle: The mini usb cable provided sticks out a great deal, and drags against the stand itself
reviewDescription: There are really no words for how awful the design of this mic is. With the built in stand, and an incredibly cheap mini usb port, my unit was non functional within a month or two of purchase. When the mic hinges, the bottom of it has minimal clearance from the stand. The mini usb cable provided sticks out a great deal, and drags against the stand itself, causing the cable to pull on the mic itself.Given some time this eventually wears down the female end of the mini usb port, and unseats it from the board. Once this happens, you are either replacing the usb port, or buying a new mic.It's a great mic, but it's designed to encourage hardware failure forcing you to buy another. I will never buy another Blue product.

I've had this microphone for a couple of years and for the first year all went well. Now it's essentially just as good as a cheap microphone that'd come with any generic brand gaming headset. This thing is falling apart, the metal mesh is somehow coming undone. The specific usb that came with it stopped working a long time ago and the mute button doesn't even work anymore. Should have saved my money or bought another gaming headset because it lasts just as long as one anyways.
Doesn't let me download drivers. Keeps telling me to plug it in, even though it's already plugged in. I should never have bought this. Totally unusable.

Worked great for a while, though I did have a problem where it would not stay muted. Light would flash red indicating that the mic was muted, but audio was being picked up. Have to toggle the mute button on/off every 5 minutes or so while muted or just will unmute itself.My main issue is that after barely any use the USB connection to the mic is so loose that any movement at all of the base, or the cord, including my leg brushing up against it, causes complete audio failure for 5 seconds.I was told this was a top-of-the-line product, but i just don't see it.

reviewTitle: Buy a new item and receive a poorly packaged returned item. USB device not recognized.
reviewDescription: This is why I hate buying from Amazon. It's so shady. The package was a returned item and repackaged poorly. There was loose rubber rings that fell out of the box when I opened it and some dark hairs sticking to the styrofoam inside.It took a lot of unplugging and plugging back in before it finally worked.I wouldn't recommend this produce. It's not much better than the built in mic for my iMac.

reviewTitle: Mic doesn't even work out of the box. And cable provided is crap. Sexy though
reviewDescription: The mic didn't work out of the box. My computer did not recognize that it was even connected. I assumed it was the crappy USB cable they provided so I bought a higher quality one, still the mic wasn't recognized to be plugged in. There was power running to the mic showing that the cable wasn't the problem, and multiple USB ports weren't the issue either.Still the mic is in recognized by my pc no matter how much trouble shooting I do.I plan to try a bit more trouble shooting because I want to like this mic, it's just so sexy... but sexy doesn't fulfill its function as a microphone. Especially a $130 microphone. This thing should work and come with a gold braided USB cable.But as for now this mic is a strightb 0/5 because of its inability to work.
Stopped working. Doesn't record a single thing after a few months. This happened to a friend too.

After seeing plenty of people use this on youtube, I figured I might as well go with this product. What a disappointment. I normally wouldn't post a review on a product unless I gave it 5 stars. This on the other hand however, was horrible. I purchased the platinum version about 2 months ago and after 2 weeks, it stopped working entirely. It didn't pick up any sound at all. I sent it back for a replacement (I had to pay $70 for shipping) and I received a replacement after 3 weeks. The replacement they gave me was silver instead of platinum which wasn't a big deal. However, none of the recording patterns worked except for the omni-directional mode. This was extremely frustrating of course but I was still willing to try using the product. After 2 weeks, the omni-directional mode no longer worked and I now have an expensive paperweight.What a beautiful white elephant. URGH.

I'm pretty sure I've had a faulty microphone for nearly a year now. I don't use it frequently, but when I try, I can never get it working right away (or at all). I have multiple Windows machines with multiple cables, and it's a gamble on whether or not the microphone will be recognized by any of them. (Some days it will. Others it won't.) I'll even leave it plugged in when it's working, shut off my computer, and it won't work the next time I power everything up.Now that I've owned this microphone for nearly a year, I'm stuck with an expensive paperweight that's hit or miss on functionality. I don't recommend this one—at least, don't buy it here.

reviewTitle: The beeping sounds like morse code
reviewDescription: I've done everything I could for this microphone to stop the distorted beeping noise but it keeps coming back!Idk if it's my earphones or laptop or my windows, but nothing helps to stop the beeping noise. I've managed to stop it to a few times a minute but it keeps bothering me no matter what happens. When I got this the noise was very bad. The system I record this on will pick up this in mic noise as well which infuriates me. I wanted this initially for asmr (so you can see why I need this to be as silent as possible, not including the white noise) but it looks like it wont happen for a month or so. Very disappointed

I purchased this Mic in July of 2022. 3 months later it just stopped working . Nothing has been done to it. It stays at the same place at all the times. It turns on , but none of my computers sees  it. I’ve tried my husbands computer, same issue. Contacted support, but of course it’s non refundable and non returnable. I wish I could exchange it. It was a good mic for 3 months . Very disappointed!

reviewTitle: the usb wire for the microphone came broken.
reviewDescription: the mic works fine but the wire it came with does not work at all.at first i thought the mic was the problem so i was worried that i had to return this and go through the hassle to do so.but later after using a wire i had for my other mic. i learned that the usb wire it came withwas broken to start with.like what is this.... i opened it, all i did was unwrap the wired wire and plug it in and its broken already.now im hearing questioning myself what if the mic breaks soon as well.how can a brand new wire break in a min after i unwrap it. was it used?is the mic used as well? like come on. man i wrote a lot... as i was writing this it got me more annoyed somehow.

This mic is fantastic. The quality is amazing and everyone that hears me talk over it completely agrees!They also agree that everything in the room with me also sounds loud and crystal clear as if it were right next to the mic regardless of location in relation to the mic.The gain switch doesn’t work and I’m not too sure if the direction settings work either. My last microphone (the blue snowball) was able to get just my voice, but this microphone is so sensitive, it was able to hear someone talking in another room. So, make sure you use this microphone in a very quiet place.Second of all, I absolutely LOVE the construction of this microphone. It has a completely metal construction with a smooth finish. Making it heavy and harder to move around when you put it on a desk keeping it in place. It also came with a long cord that was able to reach my USB port. Which was a plus also. My only complaint about this microphone is that I was not able to get a clamp pop filter on it due to the type of hinges it used to keep the microphone in place.Thirdly, the settings are OK, but they really don't make much of a difference. For instance, omnidirectional and stereo pretty much capture the same range of sound. The only difference is that stereo focuses more a bit of a "surround sound" effect while omnidirectional makes everything feel like it is in the center. The cardiac mode is good for talking because you always sound like you are in the center which is nice, and the bi-directional mode is great for interviews when you would rather use a studio quality microphone instead of the lower quality shirt clip microphones.Overall, this is an excellent microphone for the price when it comes to the construction and the sound quality. Although, if you need a surround-sound or 3D surround sound microphone, you might want to look elsewhere.

reviewTitle: Great microphone while it works.  Support nonexistent.
reviewDescription: I've used Blue Snowball microphones for years (we have two in our house) and have been very pleased with their sound and overall quality.  When my 12-year-old son wanted to play around with game broadcasting and recording tech reviews, my goto was Blue.  I wanted him to have a Blue Yeti because it would provide more features and its size makes a bold statement.  The Blue Yeti did not disappoint--for the first year.  Around the one year point, he mentioned that it was picking up a high pitched whine.  I hit Blue's website seeking help.  We found their FAQ and followed the diagnostic instructions outlined, including trying with multiple PCs and iPhones in multiple locations.  Also tried several different USB cables.  Nothing resolved the issue.  For good measure, we used one of our Blue Snowballs to test the machine that where the Yeti originally exhibited the problem.  The Snowball worked great.  After all that, I reluctantly concluded it was a bad Yeti mic.  I was shocked because the Snowballs had been so reliable for so many years.I opened a support case with Blue via their support page on Dec 31, 2018.  Their system promptly sent me an email acknowledging the case and said that I should expect to hear something in 24-48 hours.  I chuckled a little, knowing that it would likely be a little longer since the case was opened on New Year's Eve.  I expected it to be at least a couple of days after New Years Day before I got a response.  Well, it's now Jan 19 and I'm still waiting to hear back.  I've pinged the case with a "hello" message to try to get it into someone's queue.  I've also pinged Blue's Twitter account.  Nothing.  I'm disappointed.  I thought Blue stood for quality and really expected that to include quality support.  I guess I was naive to believe that Blue was different from the no-name popup companies selling on Amazon.If you are dead set on Blue, I'd stick with the Blue Snowball if it meets your needs.  It has similar sound quality for the more narrow use cases it is designed for.  It's also half the price, so you're not out as much if it dies and you can't get support.I can't predict what my son's broadcasting future will be, but I'm pretty sure he won't be thinking very highly of Blue microphones based on this experience.So, the Blue Yeti is great, while it works.  Don't expect support when it doesn't.

reviewTitle: Three dead or dying yeti in less than two years
reviewDescription: The sound quality of the yeti and clarity is the best i've ever had in a microphone.  I've gone through several headset mics and a couple different stand alone ones such as this one.Yeti #1:  It worked for about a week.  The sound quality was great but the mute button seemed to take a few presses for it to turn on and off.  Quite often I would have to hold the yeti with both hands and press the mute firmly for it to work.  Then all of a sudden, It started to give shrill feedback OR buzzing whenever I was broadcasting to people...  I contacted customer support.  They told me it was probably a bad cable after I recorded some audio and sent it to them for a listen.  They offered to send another cable for me to try but since it was still within the RMA period AND the mute button was broken... I just sent it back to Amazon for a replacement.Yeti #2:  has worked now for more than a year.  The mute button is also just as messed up on this one (and has been since day 1) but no sound quality issues... until now.  The mic started to just stop recording randomly after hours in discord and give no output.  The only way to fix it is to unplug it and re plug it in.  Now it has started to give really weird buzzing noises and I have to play with it at least once a week to get it to start working again.  I am still using this mic until I get tired enough to go find a new one.Yeti #3:  Friend really liked the sound of my mic.(6 months ago)  So he bought one.  The mute button flat out just didn't work, out of the box... you can press it and get the blinking light to start (meaning it is muted) but it still broadcasts.  When you press it again and the light is solid (not muted), it broadcasts just the same.  But the sound quality was just fine and after hearing that both of my yeti had broken mute buttons, he just decided to mute in windows.  Fast forward several months.  One random day we jumped into discord and his mic sounded really off to me... none of the knobs on the back changed the audio quality AT ALL, cardiod, omni... and so on.  It all sounded the same.  I can hear everything going on in house... wife in the next room on the phone... his dog barking in the back yard.  I believe it is stuck on the omni sound pattern though who knows...I really liked the sound quality of this mic... when it worked.  That's why I gave it two stars instead of one.

reviewTitle: Better Than a Headset Mic, Worse Than Literally Anything Else
reviewDescription: I bought this microphone expecting the audio quality to be just a little below mics that cost maybe $50 - $100 more. I was sorely disappointed. The fact of the matter is, this mic is only slightly better than your run of the mill headset microphone (in fact, my five year old $40 Turtle Beach headset had a better mic than this PoS).Simply put, unless you are recording in a perfectly sound treated room with a 100% silent computer and no A/C, you cannot use this microphone. Even with the gain on the lowest possible setting, it picks up the crickets outside my window. It picks up my neighbors (who are not connected to me) outside barbecuing. It picks up my computer, which is shocking because it's water cooled. It's incredibly quiet. So, the only time I could record was late at night, and even then I would have to run an EQ and Noise Reduction to get the crickets and PC noise out.Further, this is a condenser microphone, NOT a dynamic microphone. It picks up EVERYTHING about your voice, including heavy plosives and annoying saliva clicks. Even with a pop filter AND while speaking diagonally into the mic, it still could not filter out plosives and saliva clicks. I drank water until I was practically made of it, and I even tried the apple trick to get rid of saliva clicks. Nothing would work. This microphone is simply WAY too sensitive.On top of all that, the sound quality is just garbage. Even when running it through something like VoiceMeeter, it still just does not ever achieve a full sound.This mic is only popular because it looks cool and because it's heavy. That's it. It's complete garbage. Do yourself a favor and just save up about $700 or so over the course of several months and buy a Shure SM7B, a basic one-input interface, and a Cloudlifter. Don't even bother with this s***** toy. It's awful, and I would never recommend it to anyone, not even my worst enemy.

reviewTitle: Great product, until it's broken for no apparent reason, and can't replace thanks to the refund window.
reviewDescription: I can't put my finger on when the troubles I am having exactly started. I think it was about 1 month into having used the product.Long story short, I've all of a sudden started getting EXTREMELY LOW GAIN levels on this microphone. I've contacted support, and sent them a sample with below settings (as they've requested):Gain on Mic: 50%, 12 o’clockGain on W10: 50%, about +1.6dBPattern: Cardioid, with Blue logo facing me (obviously)I'm still waiting on the support to get back to me on this, but let me tell you: I really enjoyed the product when it was working as intended (the first 3 weeks upon arrival). I actually had to tone all the gains down and what not.On Audacity, I'm getting MAX -24dB when I'm 2 inches close to the microphone with all gains jacked up to 100%. Then it's just all noise and the waveform is super small.When I listen to myself on the Yeti (real-time, plugged into Yeti's own headphone jack) it’s the same.I haven’t dropped the hardware or done any physical damage. I mean it's been sitting on my desk the entire time, even unplugged / unpowered when not in use, so that nothing happened to my precious mic.What I'm sick of reading as potential solutions when I'm asking around are "have you reinstalled the drivers" and obvious Tech101 stuff like that. Yes, they're well intended, but I've gone as far as sniffing the USB packets sent to identify if there was any interference or if another driver that I may have installed on my Windows 10 machine was hijacking the packets and running a low pass filter or something. So yes, I'm beyond all the "uninstall reinstall drivers, remove Realtek and try again, use another cable, try another jack, try another PC" type of stuff. I'll be trying my luck tomorrow at the office with a Windows 7 PC, if I can still find one that's not upgraded to Windows 10..Closest I've gotten to any sort of useful discussion on the potential reason why it's failing is in this thread on the Microsoft forums where people are expressing similar problems with the AT2020, and a few with the Blue Yeti (not the Pro) and Blue Snowball.I'm getting closer to the point where I'll just accept that the product has gone kaput. I may have to ask for a replacement model, which is a pain, since I've ordered it from the US but I'm on the other side of the globe, let alone the replacement window being now gone since I got it at the Holiday Sale 2015.It's really sad. I think I'll move on to another microphone.

reviewTitle: Gets the job done. Be mindful of your space
reviewDescription: On it’s own, without considering the price, it’s a good product. The sound quality is good, it’s sturdy, and it comes with everything you need to get started out of the box. However. I have 2 major issues with it.One: sensitivity. I know that condenser mics are supposed to be sensitive and take in a lot of noise, but I didn’t think it would be THAT sensitive, even with the gain all the way down, it picks up every small detail outside of the room I use it in. And since I use it mainly for chatting with friends and the occasional stream, I can’t take it out In post.Two: pricing. I feel like if this mic was priced $50 cheaper, it would be a real contender for the best value for a condenser mic. However, with certain Asian brands making mics that compete with this on sound quality for a small fraction of the price it’s hard to make the argument that the yeti is valuable In that sense.In summary, If I could go back in time and change my decision, I probably would. I’d either save more and get the sm7b for its amazing dynamic sound quality, or save some cash and go with the cheaper Asian alternatives, since they have comparable quality for cheaper.

reviewTitle: Fantastic mic for a little past the warranty
reviewDescription: While it lasted this microphone was fantastic and that's the only reason it get's up to 3 stars. The sound quality is really good and at first it was definitely worth the price. The multiple settings are also useful when you're changing how many people are in a recording. For the longest time I would have given it a 5 star review but that time is past. Frankly the mini USB connector is absolute garbage and has always been that way. If you have an unchanging set up and never take the cord out then it's probably great and will work fine forever. However if you need to be constantly moving cords around and changing things up then DO NOT buy this microphone. The mini USB connector wore out bad over the years and got misshapen so much that the cord could barely stay in at all. Then just today we connected the  microphone cord and when we pulled it out and took a huge chunk of the connector with it. I have yet to figure out how this happened. Anyway you may want to consider a Yeti Nano instead. It may not be quite as good but from what I hear it uses micro USB instead which seems to be much more reliable. Like I said we had to change the cord a lot in my recording set up, so if yours is more stationary then this may work great for you.
