reviewTitle: I am a Youtuber and need to have something with great sound quality for my videos
reviewDescription: I have been using the Blue Yeti since August and have had only a couple of issues. I am a Youtuber and need to have something with great sound quality for my videos. This mic does the job and it was well worth the purchase.One of the main things I like about this mic is the fact that you can change where it picks up the audio from. Whether I am just live streaming or doing an interview I can adjust the mic accordingly. It has been extremely helpful especially when doing group gaming with my friends.What I did not like about it though is the weight. It is very sturdy, which is a great thing, but it also has enough weight on it that most stands or arms will not hold it without sagging. While that is a tiny annoyance, overall this mic is still amazing and will be the main mic for my live streaming from now on.Blue Yeti Pros and Cons:Pros:1. Amazing sound quality2. Sturdy construction3. Ability to adjust where the sound is being recorded from.4. Picks up everything.5. Connecting headset through mic (no audio lag)Cons:1. Too heavy to use with most mic stands2. Stand connection on bottom might not fit some stands3. Not really travel friendly

Have only tried one mode, so I can't speak to the other spatial pickup settings, but I have used with recording software (Cyberlink AudioDirector) and streaming (Zoom) with excellent results. Installation is super easy, immediately usable in Win 10 both for record and for playback (headphones, which also give you "live" audio from the mic for monitor functions.Four small issues: 1) part of the black paint was scratched off the grille, faint, but noticeable. 2) when muted, the LED blinks constantly (wish there was an option to turn it off short of unplugging from USB) and 3) It does pick up minor vibrations from the same work surface (as from a keyboard (yes, I know that's why you mount it from a boom or in an isolation ring) and 4) the mute button is flaky - if i just push hard enough to get a click, mute function does not always engage; works a bit better if I push harder and it seems to work differently if already muted (easier to turn mute off).None of the above issues are any great impediment to using this product, which is frankly very good at this price point, but the mute button issue can be annoying.

That program is called Krisp.  Even my elderly father hears me well now. Highly recommend this microphone.

reviewTitle: One of the best USB mics, but you’re better off buying a XLR mic instead.
reviewDescription: The blue yeti is one of the best usb microphones out there. If you’re looking for a plug & play mic with decent sound that is extremely easy to use, then this is a great option. If you’re looking for professional quality sound, however, then your much better off getting a XLR mic. Even the best USB mics can’t compare to the quality of essentially any XLR microphone. Even if you’re on a budget, you could buy a simple studio setup for almost the same amount of money as you would spend on this yeti. (For example, you could buy a $40 behringer u-phoria um2 audio interface and a MXL 990 for $70 and this cheap set up will sound way better than a usb mic like the yeti)If you just want a mic that produces decent audio for Skype, conference calls, computer games, YouTube, or podcasts, then this mic could work great for you. But if you want real professional high quality sound, I would pass on buying a blue yeti or any usb mic for that matter. It all depends on what you’re going to be using a mic for, but either way I strongly suggest to research different options before forking out any cash.

reviewTitle: Nothing Beats a Blue Yeti at This Price Point!
reviewDescription: I have been using the Logitech Blue Yeti Microphone for a few months now and I am very happy with it. This microphone is a great choice for anyone who wants to record or stream high-quality audio for various purposes, such as gaming, podcasting, music, and more.The microphone has a sleek and elegant design, with a black metal body and a sturdy base. It also comes with a USB cable and a quick start guide. The microphone is very easy to set up, just plug it into your PC or Mac and you are ready to go. The microphone is compatible with most recording and streaming software, such as Audacity, OBS, Skype, and more.The microphone has four different pickup patterns: cardioid, omnidirectional, bidirectional, and stereo. You can switch between them by using the knob on the back of the microphone. Each pattern has its own advantages and disadvantages, depending on what you want to record or stream. For example, cardioid is good for solo vocals or instruments, omnidirectional is good for capturing sound from all directions, bidirectional is good for interviews or duets, and stereo is good for creating a realistic sound image.The microphone also has onboard audio controls on the front of the microphone. You can adjust the headphone volume, mute the microphone, and change the mic gain by using the buttons and knobs. The microphone also has a 3.5 mm headphone jack that allows you to monitor your sound in real time without any latency.The microphone delivers clear, powerful, and broadcast-quality sound for any application. The microphone has a custom three-capsule array that produces rich and detailed sound with minimal distortion and noise. The microphone also supports Blue VO!CE software, which allows you to craft the perfect vocal sound and entertain your audience with enhanced effects, advanced modulation, and HD audio samples. You can access Blue VO!CE by downloading Logitech’s free G HUB software.The Logitech Blue Yeti Microphone is one of the best microphones I have ever used. It offers outstanding performance, versatility, and ease of use. It is also very affordable. I highly recommend this microphone to anyone who is looking for an upgrade or a new purchase.

reviewTitle: Perfect mic for streaming and gaming
reviewDescription: I recently picked up the Blue Yeti USB Microphone and I must say, it has completely elevated my gaming and streaming experience. The sound quality is phenomenal; my voice comes through crystal clear, which is a huge improvement and something my audience immediately noticed and complimented. The Yeti offers multiple pattern settings which are fantastic for different scenarios, whether I’m live streaming, chatting with my team, or recording content.The setup was a breeze; just plug and play with my PC, no additional drivers needed. It’s also very sturdy and well-built, which is great for lasting durability. The design is sleek and fits well with my gaming setup, which is a nice bonus.The real-time feedback through the headphone jack is another feature that I found incredibly useful, especially to monitor and adjust mic levels. It’s definitely a standout feature for live streaming.All in all, the Blue Yeti is a top-tier microphone that offers professional-quality sound for gamers and creators alike. It’s a solid investment that has not only met but exceeded my expectations. Highly recommended for anyone looking to seriously upgrade their audio game!

reviewTitle: It's alright for content creation and gaming, but perfect for things like ASMR
reviewDescription: I purchased this Blue Yeti a long time ago to give myself time to try it out, and also because I wanted both a mic for content creation and the possible hopes to start an ASMR channel (but that plan fell through), so here is my honest opinion.I create content online, stream, and game with friends in my free time; a Blue Yeti is super hard to get perfect settings to make sure the mic's sensitivity does not pick up everything like background noise, cars driving past, breathing, sounds from your mouth, etc. I have tried many filters through OBS, a pop filter, and a foam cover and never got it to sound right, but it is probably because my house is not soundproof and has thin walls. If you have a pretty good soundproof room and have good settings to make it sound good, a Blue Yeti is not bad for you, but if you don't; I recommend a condenser mic.But... if you do content like ASMR, a Blue Yeti is what you need. The sensitivity easily picks up whispers, breathing, and all different kinds of sounds. It also gives you the capability to do binaural audio for ear-to-ear action.So overall: the sound quality of a Blue Yeti is not bad, if you have god-tier settings and a good soundproof room, this mic won't pick up everything and can be great for content creation, but if you're looking to do ASMR content, this mic is perfect from how much sound it can pick up. I don't hate or regret my purchase, as I may use this mic sometime for something like ASMR, but it wasn't good for gaming and content creation for me!

reviewDescription: I loved this mic, at first. It was what I thought to be the overall most versatile mic I could use, all in order to justify a price like this (~$115 at my time). reviewTitle: Make sure you'll use the most it has to offer.
reviewDescription: Very good Microphone. I upgraded from my Logitech G430 built-in Mic on the headset, and the difference is massive: My voice is much, much more clear. About 2 weeks later Windows claimed that a "Driver" was incorrect, and tried to fix it on the Device Manager. There was no error at all, but it said there was, and tried to repair. Windows failed and ended up unistalling the drivers, and now the Mic is recognized as a normal Mic, not Blue Yeti, making it impossible to use the Headphone Jack feature that it has to check your own voice. Real bummer. Did not found a Fix, but an entire OS Reinstall should do the job for windows to recognize it as a new device again and install the drivers.Now, do make sure you are using all it has to offer: Some games Built In Voice Chat do not get the true quality the Yeti has. Personally I use Discord, and the Audio Quality there is better, according to my friends.Last thing: Do put it close to your mouth, and set the Audio sensitivity on Windows to 50%, and set the Gain on the Yeti just a little bit after the letter N on the gain. That way your voice will sound really good.Expensive, but if you are a Youtuber, Streamer, Casual gamer that uses the Voice Chat a lot, I do recommend this device if you're planning on stepping up your Microphone.

I've spent a few months using this device before I decided to review it. Not going to lie, probably the best microphone I have ever purchased. I personally record videos on my android phone (S22) but I didn't see any reviews so far mention if the mic's USB cable would be able to successfully connect to a phone using an adapter...So, "does the mic's USB cable work with USB adapters?" This thing has changed my recording life and I haven't even recorded yet. A few voice snippets here and there to test the microphone and see how I sounded via different settings and I can safely say the following:Audibly without this, I hate the sound of my voice. And I realized why my wife likes it when I talk. It's not the best, but it's not the worst.The microphone definitely picks up...Everything. And unlike the pictures here, it's more of a slick matte black. And I'm happy to say that the finish is good on fingerprints (not that you'll touch it much when you get it set up where you want it) and the included stand is both sturdy and works QUITE well. reviewTitle: GREAT for ASMR! If you pass the learning curve
reviewDescription: I previously gave this mic 2 stars. But after using it for almost 1 year, I have figured out how to get GREAT sound from it for my ASMR videos.Put a foam cover on itRecord with gain at 9:00Use the multipressor plugin in GarageBand, set around 10Use the deesser pluginEq the highs to 9:00, lows to around 9:00, and mids along with the mid frequency pretty much all the way downAdjust the equalizer manually tooTHE TRICK AND MOST IMPORTANT THING!! Watch the master volume level meter during playback and make sure it does not go into the red! Do this in GarageBand and iMovie or final cut. If the track volume or master volume are hittin the red the audio will be distorted on export or upload. Took me forever to learn that. You may sometimes need to push the “a” key to open up the automation thing in GarageBand and manually lower spots where the audio is peaking into the red. Same with iMovie or final cut. Once I get into the video editor, I raise the whole audio level as much as possible until it barely hits the yellow in some places. If some places hit the red I will cut around those points and manually lower them. Hope this helps any other ASMRtists trying to get good sound. There IS NOT a good video on YouTube to show you. They all leave out the most important things. Blue Yeti really should include a slip of paper that has some recommendations for different types of recording and how to get the best sound.

The sound quality is amazing.  I can even hear myself typing on the other end of the conversation.  It picks up everything.  I use this for my telehealth sessions with my clients and they can hear everything I'm saying.  The volume control is great.  The little knob is perfect.

reviewTitle: My kid said it was “the one”
reviewDescription: I ordered this mic for my awesome computer nerd kid for her 16th Christmas. I did my research a bit, but honestly ordered due to the right combination of rating and price. reviewTitle: It’s so good, it picks up all the sounds around me
reviewDescription: When I record videos, you can sometimes hear my family from other rooms because it is so sensitive. Easy volume control. Easy set up. Love this product.

I use it for recording acoustic guitar and vocals and the sound quality is superb. I see a few reviews that say there's was old/used or damaged but mine is in excellent condition, if it's not new and unused I'd never know it.

reviewTitle: Requires lots of tuning and love and care, but well worth it. 6 years of use strong!
reviewDescription: I bought this Blue Yeti Blackout almost 6 years ago on an Amazon lightning deal for $75. I'm very glad I did as I have not seen the price go anywhere near that low in all of those years since. I used this microphone as my daily microphone while gaming/working for the better part of 4 years, before switching to my current wireless headset; but I still break it out and use it whenever I'm going to record a video or give a professional presentation in front of a wider audience. This microphone is a true studio-quality microphone, from a well known brand, for less than $100. With that said, it by no means is plug-and-play, it requires lots of tuning, learning, and attention to detail to make it the truly incredible microphone that it is. I personally have had to turn down the microphone input volume in my Windows settings and manually adjust the gain on the microphone to compensate, and I use a noise suppression filter in OBS when recording, as I live on a busy street; but your mileage will vary. I have no idea if there are better options out there, but the Mics I have seen in person that compare to the Yeti Blackout are nowhere near as hefty and sturdy. At the time I purchased this microphone, it was really the only logical option in this price range; and I am incredibly impressed that it has held up all these years later.

reviewTitle: Once I figured out how to get it to output sound it was great.
reviewDescription: This is supposed to be plug-and-play, and maybe it is for some folks. I have a Surface Laptop, a Dell Laptop, and an HP desktop. Couldn't get any sound out of it on any of them. Thank god for YouTube. For PCs, you need to go to SETTINGS >SYSTEM>SOUND. For OUTPUT make sure to select your computer speakers and not the microphone. For INPUT select Yeti Microphone. You should be good to go.Sound quality is really good.
Reviews say this is a GREAT mic. So far, have to agree with the reviews.Plug and Play. Great sound. Easy to adjust direction and gain.

reviewTitle: You Should Geti a Blue Yeti!
reviewDescription: I absolutely LOVE this microphone. I am using it primarily to record and produce high quality Voiceover work. The mic is substantial and solidly built.  It is quite heavy. If you choose to use it as I do, suspended from above and attached to an Aluminum shock mount, you will have to invest in a higher quality scissor boom arm in order to hold the weight. I went ahead and spent the $100 to get the Rode Scissor boom arm which holds the shock mount, the mic and a pop filter without any drooping or jeopardy.  I love that the mic is a usb mic (meaning the analog to digital conversion circuitry is built into the mic) allowing me to connect it directly into my Mac. The sound quality with voice is outstanding providing a professional level end product. The mic has 4 different settings (which I suppose is nice for different applications) but I use it exclusively in Cardioid mode. The mic has a conveniently placed jack (on the bottom... or top in my configuration) for connecting studio monitor headphones. There is a volume control knob for the headphone volume as well as a mute button on the front of the mic. On the rear is the gain control knob and the recording mode selector knob. The knobs are solid, well placed and easy to use. If you choose to use this on a desktop surface you will appreciate the solidness and height of the included mic stand. The stand raises the mic much higher than most mic stands, putting it at a very reasonable height for speaking directly into the front of the mic while sitting at your desk. The only problem seems to be that there is really no way to mount a shock mount to the Blue Yeti stand. All in all this is an exceptionally built condenser microphone with great features that can produce tremendously professional home studio sound for voiceover work and all for less than $150.

reviewTitle: Definitely get soundwork done in your room!
reviewDescription: This microphone has several modes, find the one that suits your room! I will warn you however, this is a professional-quality mic. If your room is not prepared well for a compression mic like this, it may become apparent to the other end of the mic that it isn't.

reviewTitle: Big Shock to Nobody - It's awesome
reviewDescription: The Yeti is, as most people should know, a great sounding microphone and will get 99% of end users throughout their day without any problems. It's easy to install with no drivers to download and has way more options than the Snowball directly on the mic. The mute button is a great help too, I no longer have to alt tab things to find the mute on whatever chat service I'm using at the time.I still believe most people could get by just fine using a Blue Snowball or Snowflake, especially if you want one that's easier to carry, but if you want something that's "just extra" and is great for a huge number of things from music to webcams to conferences to whatever else, it's hard to suggest anything else.The included stand works well and is a million times better than the one that comes with the Snowball, but I wish the large thumb screws on either side could tighten into the microphone a little bit more as I find the Yeti falling onto its back often whenever I'm moving things around my desk. This is solved by getting a sturdy microphone stand and a shock mount so you don't get vibrations, but if you're not too worried about perfectly baritone voices then the included stand does a decent job of softening desk movements and shakes. Nobody I've talked to has heard much background noise and I haven't heard any hisses or crackles during my Audacity recordings. The USB cable is long too, and longer cables is always a good thing. I don't know if it's just my microphone but the USB plug on the Yeti is a little loose and doesn't grip the cable as hard as I'd like. If the cable gets tugged it'll fall out, which is more annoying than anything. Other than that I'm extremely happy with it and will probably use it until it breaks, if it ever does.
Super easy to setup and adjust and the sound quality is great. I use this with a pop filter and my videos have gone up in views ever since I’ve started recording with this.
My fiance loved his birthday gift!

As my favorite color blue, the Blue Yeti USB Microphone comes in the color black, and it looks very attractive. I have not used this microphone in months because my Dell microcomputer already has a built-in camera and microphone. The Blue Yeti microphone poses on my studio desk like a souvenir prop, even though I do more business productivity than podcasting.
No complaints, great mic!

reviewTitle: Mi primer micrófono, según mi criterio es excelente
reviewDescription: No soy experto en el tema del sonido pero si puedo afirmar que la calidad de sonido de este microfono es abismalmente mejor al de usar el del portátil y el del smartphone, es sonido es más fluido sin duda alguna.En cuanto a calidad de construcción parece que durará toda la vida, su construcción es en aluminio de alta calidad.Tengo entendido que este es o fue el micrófono más usado por los streamers por un buen tiempo y no ha pasado de moda, yo me fié de eso para realizar esta compra, en realidad estoy contento con el y lo encuentro muy versátil.
Great mic by a trusted brand.

Great sound and recording capabilities.  I use it for making my audio videos in PowerPoint.  It's a great microphone system to have for recording and playback!!  Thanks Amazon and Market Seller for a fantastic product!!
Very pleased with this microphone. Sound quality is excellent!

Seriously such good quality!!! Hooked it up and it worked right away. If you’re thinking about buying it just buy it!!!!

reviewTitle: Well Made Microphone - Mini usb type questionable
reviewDescription: Mic is well made and well optioned. Usable for live streaming and other uses with it's wide selection of modes - which work !!My problem is with the mini USB adapter on the back end of the Mic - it sometimes disconnects from the computer and has to be un plugged and then plugged in multiple times before the computer will recognize it.No idea why they chose this mini USB plug but i warn you not to move it during taping or it will disconnect.Otherwise there is nothing but good things to say about this heavy, well made construction. The different Modes and Gain setting are nice to have. It also has a head phones out so you can check your level.I would recommend this mic to others.

I have a Blackout and until recently I had nothing but good things to say about it.But the cable they gave me was shoddy and snapped off after some use,pop filters are more than a bit of a pain to attach and keep on,and the headphone plug got worn and loose so the sound now gives out.They have a 2 year manufacturer warranty I believe,but after 2 weeks of emails that have requested a voice sample I am unable to provide followed by no response until I send the same email,I would recommend purchasing with a third party warranty as the non-manufacturer one instantly replaces the product with a new one if you run into any trouble.If you're unable to purchase with warranty from the retailer,I would avoid and check out the Audio Technica AT 2020** even at promo price.EDIT: Or AT 2100 depending on budget/suitability.

Especially on a physical button where it's clearly not user error or touch screen related.The mic has not been abused in any way so I can only surmise that it has poor quality contacts or build quality internally. Kind of frustrating for how expensive the mic is.

It's just marginally better than the $30 Maono. The only reason I kept it was for the Cardioid/Omni/Figure-8/Stereo patterns, which work as expected for the price point. The biggest draw back is the fact that I have to unplug the mic and plug it back in every time I boot up the PC to record. I've never run into this issue with any other mic and I am using the same USB 3.0 port that I have always used (direct input to the Motherboard, with no decks or controllers in between).

They are still manufacturing this thing as USB mini, the port barely holds cables, and the cord is constantly disconnecting, and you wouldn't know unless you're listening to your audio realtime. This makes the microphone almost competently useless.The laziness to not update this +10 year old product... please support manufactures creating new mics.

i had been using this mic for around 2 years and one day it just poof, stopped working properly and it sounded like a wendy's drive through. otherwise this is def a nice mic, just really upset it stopped working :\

It was covered under the warranty. But he was without a mic for about 6 weeks. It worked fine after that so I’m changing my review to 3 stars.

reviewTitle: This Mic is good only if you can speak into it from 3ft away.
reviewDescription: If you try to use it for a choir with a few people in a large room with other instruments, you will notice that it is not at all good mic. The snow ball mic also is equally good for that use. my rating for this mic is only 2 or3 out of 5. There are many other Mics that sound better than this.

reviewTitle: It may fall apart the day after you warranty expires.
reviewDescription: It's lucky I gave it 3 stars. I've had this mic for just over 2 years. It has a 2 year manufacturer's warranty. After 2 years and 1 month, it stops detecting as a Blue Yeti on any computer and shows up as "USB Advanced Audio." People on the other end can still hear me and it will still record, but I can't hear myself through headphones connected to the mic anymore. I did some research and found out that this is a common problem with both the Yeti and the Snowball.Also, the quality when recording now that it doesn't show up as a Blue Yeti is no better than the cheapest mics out there.

reviewTitle: Right out of the box-- Mute button does not work
reviewDescription: I ordered this product yesterday, and received it today-- I was very excited. The sound seems good, though I'll need more time to really know how it does. However, right out of the box, the mute button does not work. At all. I don't really need a mute button for my purposes, BUT someone out there might.  And the product is brand new, so the button really should work fresh out of the box. I'm concerned that that doesn't bode well for the life of the microphone, but I'm going to give it a shot.

The product we received was defective from the moment we took it out of the box. Didn't work with our iMac.We called Blue Microphones customer service. Their representative tried to get the product to work but could not.So, he offered to send us a new product to replace the defective one and also told us that we don't need to ship the defective microphone back to them. Instead, we received e-mails telling us that our claim is been evaluated, and another e-mail asking us to show them proof that we shipped the defective product even though we were told that it's not needed.Bottom line: bad product + bad service = one huge disappointment.

I purchased this item on march 15, 2018.As of this month February 2020, it is no longer working.The warranty is 24 months.  Luckily my Yeti died on the 23rd month.  BUT the replacement process is long and tedious..they will only email you.  The final steps will be to have you damage the yeti's input port and then they will require you to write your customer number in permanent ink near the damaged port.  I used white tape to write my number and they are having me do it over.Im not joking.  The replacement process is RIDICULOUS.  I'm retired so i look foward to play this game.  I can hardly wait to get the next step in the replacement process game.My suggestion....by any other microphone.  Avoid this product.  Anything else would be better.I hope to get a replacement before i die.  It may take that long.

Unfortunately my Yeti fell victim to the USB on the device failing. The mic has been suspended from a microphone arm with plenty of cable and was out of the way from being touched or hit. However, with all of these things, the device USB has died anyway. So maybe don't talk to loud into the microphone or yours will also passively aggressively end its functionality.Blue support has been pretty poor. Going with another company for future audio purchases.

Beware! Item wasn’t advertised as used but when it arrived it came with a slip describing it as “used-good condition” I paid as much for this as a new one, but since it was staring me in the face I was willing to give it a try. reviewTitle: Excellent Sound Quality, but Failed After One Use
reviewDescription: User-friendly and easy to set up with excellent recording quality. I recorded audio for my dad's 60th birthday using this microphone and it was crystal clear and pleasant; however, I only got to use it one time. The following week, I turned my laptop on and tried to use the microphone, but it wouldn't pick up any sound. My laptop recognized the microphone as a device, but Audacity indicated it couldn't pick up any input. After a couple minutes I noticed a burning smell coming from the metallic screen at the top of the microphone. Nervous, I unplugged the microphone, rebooted my laptop, and tried again, but obtained the same results and same burning smell. I then tried the microphone on a different laptop, but again obtained the same results. Very disappointed that a $115 microphone can only be used one time before burning up.

This product worked for about a month and then stopped working. After some research apparently this is a widespread problem for this mic where it does not work with the Mac Mini using Apples M1 chip. Given that the questions on the forums go back six months it appears that this is a long term issue. I've owned at least three Blue mics and they have all been great, but I'm going to have to buy something else given I can't wait another six months to have a working mic. It's been a disappointing experience for a brand I have always thought of as being highly trustworthy and a go to...In general I would not recommend purchase for a Mac as I have read this problem extends beyond just my experience with the Mac Mini.

The overall mic is absolutely amazing but recommend from a different supplier. I have previously borrowed this mic for two weeks from a friend before making a purchase of one of my own which I ended up returning twice. You can get very well quality sound from this mic. But when I bought the mics within an hour of testing both mics didn’t pass my does everything work test. The issue was that the stereo volume wasn’t coming out evenly across the two mic channels.

I had this for a long time and it worked pretty well and it picked up a lot of subtle things.  Soon as Feb. 12th, 2020, my pc stopped recognizing it. So I figure it could be something with my drivers so I just pc reset cause I didn't have much to lose anyway. To be my surprise it still doesn't work. Sure will light up and it's on so not the cord cause I just went and got it replaced just to be sure so it's not that. It just doesn't work at all anymore which is sad that I will have to spend money on another mic because my pc doesn't recognize anymore. I didn't even touch its settings. Despite my review. Its a good product but just didnt last long as i thought it would.
Mute button does not come off and will not allow me to record.

reviewTitle: It was great while it lasted
reviewDescription: It was great while it lasted.  The audio quality was great, even if the mic picked up keyboard/mouse noises way too readily.  Even with the directional cardioid setting with the mic at least 2 feet in front of the keyboard and the gain way down, it picked up like it was right next to it.However, 3 months later the cardioid setting stopped picking up any audio.  I switched to stereo and went back to recording.  Then 2-3 weeks later the pickup from stereo dropped to a whisper.  I tested the other settings and got no audio from any of them.  The only way I could get sound was to put the mic 1-2 inch from my face and crank up the gain to max.  I have contacted Blue but have yet to receive a response after a week.  And since I'm past the Amazon return period, this is quite frustrating.

reviewTitle: Sound quality is great but some issues
reviewDescription: First off let me say the sound quality on this mic is incredible. If you are coming from a builtin mic on a webcam your mind will be blown. I won't talk about this much because all the other reviews mention this and go into detail about it. Seriously this mic is amazing.Having said that, the design of the stand it comes with is horrendous. Adjusting the mic at any angle other than standing straight up bends and breaks the USB cable immediately.  Literally the first 5 seconds of owning the device I plugged it in and adjusted the mic which broke the USB cable. Luckily my headphones were not plugged into it either or it might of broke that as well. It was an easy fix as I had an extra cable sitting around. The photo shows the now broken USB cable.Also, this works on Linux somewhat but you CANNOT hear your own voice as you would with windows. I did not dock an stars for this as it was not advertised to work with Linux. Sound quality on Linux is the same. I have not found a workaround (without using software which causes a delay) but if someone knows of one please let me know!
Requires additional software I think to make it sound amazing

Well, the mic seems great. Some preliminary tests for Twitch streaming indicate that it is pretty sensitive even in the uni-directional mode and can possibly pick up some background noise/conversation.HOWEVERThe USB cable that came with it had a short. I first noticed it because the mic did not work. When I went to unplug it the cable was ridiculously hot; the metal was hot enough to burn skin. I unplugged both ends and let it cool. Unfortunately I wasn't smart enough to pitch the cable at that point, so I tried it again! Miraculously it worked! For 0.68 seconds. At which point the mic shut off and Windows 10 started repeated messages that "A USB Device requires more power than this port can provide" over and over. All my USB devices stopped working. Unplugging the bad cable had no effect; Windows continued to blare out warnings and USB devices were disabled. I quickly powered down the machine and rebooted. My keyboard still did not work until I unplugged it and plugged it back in. WHEW. For a few horrifying minutes I thought that my motherboard was fried due to a $3 USB cable.TL;DR: Mic good, but the USB cable was crafted by Satan

reviewTitle: Charging Port Slipped or Broke/Won't work after 2 yrs
reviewDescription: After 2 years of not too much use, the charging port for the USB became loose and the power went in and out. I tried taping it in place, but that didn't work very well. Had a mechanical friend look at it and he said the port had slipped down from where it was supposed to be. We watched a youtube video on how to repair it—evidently this is fairly common—and it was incredibly complicated. So I am about to try and contact Logitech. . . rrrrgh!

reviewTitle: Don't buy two... only one will work...
reviewDescription: So, the headline is accurate... but, you may not need two microphones and in that case you will never have this problem.I bought two microphones to use for podcasting... the only thing is, these microphones have the exact same digital footprint (serial number/firmware number), so my iMac will only recognize one of these at a time. The last one plugged in becomes the active mic and the other goes into nowheres land. The computer is confused as it thinks they are the same thing. I reached out to Blue, who said they could update the mic with a new firmware to give it a new digital serial number. I thought... awesome!!! They said I had to pay for shipping to them and they will pay to ship it back once updated. Great! I did and they did.Only issue is, the mic came back exactly the same. They didn't do anything. I emailed them upon receipt and have had no response. I'm pretty sure the tech who received it just checked it to make sure it worked and sent it back. Yay! Glad I spent $17 to ship this to you for no reason ;P

I was happy to receive the Mic & Couldn't wait to use it. The box was a little damaged. The mic itself had minor scuffsWorst part was that the port was damaged. I think it was a Defective item. Will be returning & buying another.

reviewTitle: Blue Yeti is not for everybody
reviewDescription: The microphone is actually very good, but it is no suitable for everybody. In my case I would return it if I could.If you are going to record inside an untreated room where you can hear some noise from your neighbors and the street, you should better be looking at dynamic microphones instead of this one (e.g. sm7b, sm58)The Blue Yeti is very sensitive, you can set gain and record volume in any way you can possibly imagine and the result would be garbage. Your audio will contain a lot of noise that is very hard to fix within the audio. Audio patterns make no so much difference, you can barely tell the difference between one pattern or another.If you are going to record your audio in a quite place or a room with sound treatment then this could be the mic for you. But if not, don't pull the trigger here, there are better options on dynamic mics for the same price.

Every so often, there will be hissing or static coming from the mic. I never change the gain or volume settings, so this is very frustrating. I've tried re-plugging everything and nothing helps. It eventually goes away on its own to return later. Also, with KZ iems, there's a constant hissing sound which I do not get when I plug the iems directly into my computer front panel or any other devices.

had this for a few years now, for its price point it is decent, tho I will say I haven't used any other mic's around the same price point so there isn't anything for me to compare it too. The build for it is pretty solid, the sound isn't the best even with the mixer I use, but it might just be because I have too much bass in my voice or something.

reviewTitle: Good sound quality, but depends on usage
reviewDescription: Stuff everyone will care about:- Very good sound quality, far more natural sounding than my Zalman clip on mic.- Larger than I was expecting, which limited placement options (don't expect to have this between you and the monitor, as it will block it)- Knobs feel cheap.  Volume and gain weren't smooth throughout their range, and the pattern knob was very stiff.  No quick way to turn off mic when not in use, options are to mute (flashing red light) or have active (red light).Stuff gamers will care about:- I had hoped that when using headphones, I'd be able to configure the pattern/gain to prevent the pickup of keyboard (Cherry MX browns) and mouse noise, but this wasn't the case.  Varying the placement/pattern/gain didn't make much of a difference, unless I lowered the gain to the point where my voice was too low.  I was surprised it picked up so much more noise than the Zalman, which is omnidirectional.- Steam compresses audio to the point where most of the improvement over the Zalman was erased.- USB means I couldn't run it through my soundcard, which made it less convenient.

I bought this to use simply for video calls in a home office.  My office has mostly hard surfaces so using my laptop speaker and mic created a strong echo.  I also used airpods but got tired of wearing them for hours at a time. The ability to switch between polar patterns with a turn of a dial allows for extreme versatility.  I really like the headphone jack on the mic that allows you to hear yourself.  The mic also acts as a pass through audio source, so you can plug your headphones into the mic to hear both the audio from your computer.The mic stand itself works if you don't need to have anything directly in front of you like a keyboard, however if you're going to use this mic for streaming video games, or any activity that requires you to be able to move freely in front of you, I would highly suggest picking up a boom scissor arm type stand. The boom mic will attach directly to the body of the mic which can allow for some mechanically transmitted noise.This mic is definitely on the heavier side, however it does make the mic feel a little more robust and sturdy. reviewTitle: Love it! The only USB mic with self-listening option.
reviewDescription: The exact diameter of the head is 2.55" = 64 mm.This one is best! It is the only USB mic allowing to hear your own voice while talking. If  you really care how you sound in real time, this is the only option for you. You also hear the other side in skype, hangouts and other conference calls and webinars, but you hear yourself in real time. This is a great feature. THe problem with other USB mics, is that with USB option, there is a 200-400 msec delay which makes it impossible to speak and listen to yourself at the same time. You start to stagger. In this one, the sound doesn't go via USB and computer, it is returned to you directly from the mic, there is a 3.5 mm mother jack on the mic. So there is no delay (it goes via analog path), so you get realtime feedback, which is great.And the second advantage is that it is incredibly sensitive - great dinamic range in lower volume. You don't have to speak loud. You can speak normal voice even a meter away and it will record perfectly.The drawback is that it is very sensitive to knocking on the table. You can not have your elbows on the table and can not type while speaking. So you got to buy a mic stand. For a mic stand, this mic is a bit too heavy, it turns the stand over, because it is heavy. So I attached 3 big coke bottles to the bottom stem of the stand and attached using wide skotch tape. THat made the stand really heavy and now it holds this mic just fine, very stable. So now, I can lean on the table and have a mic near me.The controls are very handy on the mic. The analogue volume dial for listening the feedback is very handy.Overall love it!

I bought this so that I would be able to record clear audio without the static noise you would hear on most gaming headset/microphones.It's easy to set up, merely connect the included cable into both the microphone and usb port on your PC. What I really like about it is that it also tells you what the different modes are recommended for. the "omni-directional" mode is recommended for instrumental recording, or group singing, etc etc. It is very friendly towards beginners, especially me since this is my first dedicated microphone.Since you now have a dedicated microphone, why need your gaming headset right? The microphone even has a headphone jack so you can throw away that $100 headset and use your apple earbuds or whatever 3.5mm earphone you use. On the front of the microphone there is a dedicated volume knob and a mute button that flashes red, indicating that it is muted. On the back there is the knob for switching between the different modes the microphone can be as well as a knob to turn up or down how loud the microphone projects the sound it records. "Gains" is what the knob is labeled.Microphone itself is very well made. Heavy steel (I think its steel?) as a base and a lighter, but still metal body. There are knobs for you to adjust the angle of the microphone, or even unscrew the base so that you can mount on an elevated mount.The quality of the microphone is superb. It pretty much picks up everything. From mechanical keyboard clicks to you swallowing just a bit loudly. Very very excellent.So in all, was the 130ish dollars I spent on the product worth it? Yes. Considering how well the microphone sounds and the fact that I will be using this when I stream on twitch and record commentary for youtube videos, I feel like this is a very good investment this should probably last me for a couple of years.

reviewTitle: the Blue Yeti is easily compatible with both systems and doesn't need to install ...
reviewDescription: As someone with growing history in the radio business, when it came time to look for portable recording microphones (like it or not), the Blue Yeti was the name that just kept coming back up. Whether it was mentioned in reviews for other microphone setups, whispered on the grapevine or just frequently coming up in a Google search, the Blue Yeti seemed to be the X that marked the treasure spot on the journey of USB mics.And as far as expectations go, the Yeti is indeed that treasure (and a mighty affordable gold and glittery gem at that). While I still haven't been able to put it through it's full paces as of yet (since my main use is for voicetracking) I can't speak to the strength of all the microphone settings, but the cardioid setting has been absolutely incredible. I would say quality-wise it surpasses the overhead mounted mics at my workplace in both sheer sound quality as well as tone, and with a simple USB attachment it's a cakewalk to set it up with something as big as a full tower PC or a thin Macbook Pro without breaking much of a sweat. As you might have guessed, the Blue Yeti is easily compatible with both systems and doesn't need to install drivers or cause much interruption for it to get started working.Otherwise, it's pretty easy to lock it into the mount where you want it to be, plus it has a handy mute button on the front should you need it as well as a basic attachment in which to plug in any stock pair of headphones. I personally use noise canceling Beats headphones, which are great because it takes what sound you're feeding into the microphone and feeds it directly to your ears without any kind of delay. It can be a bit of a drawback if you're working on finer production work and don't have another way of externally hearing what you're working on (leading to some vocal/music balance issues), but it's a great setup for any of your personal recording studio aspirations. You can also mount a pop filter to the back frame behind the mic should you so desire, but it isn't always a perfect fit as it wasn't really designed for that seemingly, so you'd have to fiddle with it a bit.Take it from this voice tracker and radio jack of all trades, you can definitely trust the Blue Yeti USB Microphone for great performance and reliability (and that price tag is still pretty sweet for what you're getting too!). 10/10!

Gaming, Voice-Recording, Work Meetings. This is where I use my Blue Yeti USB Mic.Everywhere people are always asking me "What kind of mic do you have, your voice is so clear". And I'm like "Blue Yeti".  You can hear the envy in their voices as they say "Oh, that's cool. So you don't have a headset".  As I hear this response, over and over, I stare blankly into my monitor and wonder what has happened to society. Do people not know that one can own more than 1 microphone, does one not know that you can select in your settings which microphone to use. Am I the only person in the world who wears a headset and talks through a Blue Yeti... Of course not, I've seen people do this on YouTube for years.... So I respond back with "Yeah, I use a headset but I disable the microphone in it and use the Blue Yeti" only to hear the inevitable response of "Oh, why do you have a separate mic" .... I start pondering life at this point. I want to say "Ummm because I wanted high quality which you commented on to start this conversation in the first place. I mean, didn't you go "What mic are you using" because you were hearing me in crystal clear hd glory?" but instead I respond with "Because the sound quality is better on the stand-a-lone mic" .  Then I always get the same response "Yeah, but I wouldn't like having to speak into the microphone while I'm gaming. Plus, $99 for a microphone is pretty expensive" says the dude wearing a $300 headset that has inferior mic quality AND inferior sound quality to my $200 complete setup.Ughhh. You don't have to speak directly into the mic. There are adjustments that can change where the direction of the sound is recorded from. You can change the Gain on the mic itself, which is huge because some apps amplify sounds which is annoying without having the ability to quickly adjust your microphone.If you are looking for a great USB microphone this is my favorite one. Feels solid, sounds great, and has been working for quite a while now.

reviewTitle: It has amazing sound quality for a consumer grade product.
reviewDescription: I loved it, I only had it for a few days because I gave it to a friend but I tested it and the audio is SO clean and natural for such a cheap average-joe product not professional grade thing that I was amazed, but, there are problems, that I luckily never had to deal with, it is really heavy, so to mount it on an arm, many arms would probably fall or hang, and the anti vibration mount, you need to buy one made for this exact mic just as the arm.. if you are not willing to deal with these problems, get an AT2020 it has almost the same sound, it comes from a professional grade mic turned into a consumer grade one making it USB instead of XLR, it is much smaller, simpler, but there are no gain controls like on the yeti or mic monitoring or all that, the simple AT2020 is just a mic, there is a version with different patterns and mic monitoring and all that but it is more expensive, but it fits in all average arms and shock mounts. On the yeti the propietary ones are more expensive so it is up to you to decide basically which you like more, the sound is almost the same, they are really alike so it is just about the size and weather that is a problem for you, for me personally, I love them both, but for the size I would choose the AT2020, if the yeti fit in every shock mounts and arms, I would buy the yeti first just because I already used it and liked it a lot, and it is cheaper than the version of the AT2020 that has the same features.(Also, if you were wondering, yes, you can use this mic or any USB mic via OTG cable with android assuming your android has OTG support, tried with my Z2 with an app that records lossless and yes, the quality is the same from the phone or the PC doing this) Why would you want to do this, in my case, my PC after watercooling it, it makes more noise than when it was cooler by air, and the mic picks up that buzzing of the pump, so I power it off whenever I am going to record but since it is USB, I wondered if I could use it with my phone and yes you can so, the more you know the better.
